doc.title: BOC Hong Kong Holdings Ltd
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-30/BOC Hong Kong Holdings Ltd 1H25 net profit beat with enhanced provisioningBOC Hong Kong Holdings Ltd 1H25 net profit bea_2025-08-30

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 37.66 HKD | Price: 35.22 HKD

BOCHK's 1H net profit/PPOP grew 10.5%/16.5% YoY to HKD22.2bn/31.7bn, beat consensus by 6%/10%. 1H DPS rose 1.8% YoY to HKD0.58 with payout ratio down to 27.7%, although BOCHK looks to raise full year payout steadily. CET1 ratio rose 3.7ppt HoH to 23.7%, partly boosted by the new Basel III. We raise 25E EPS by 10% and keep 26-27E EPS largely stable,roll over the valuation base from 25E to average 25-26E, reduce COE by 50bp to 10.0% on lower risk-free rate, thus lift PO by 13.8% from HKD33.10 to HKD37.66. Reiterate Buy on its peer-leading growth, better risk management, attractive valuation, and high dividend yield.

NIM, after adjusting for swap costs, declined 2bp QoQ to 1.53% in 2Q25, or down 13bp HoH (vs HSB/BEA: -14bp/-20bp HoH). NII fell 3.5% YoY in 1H. Loans grew 2.0% HoH/0.5% YoY in 1H, with onshore corporate loans/onshore retail loans/offshore loans up 1.6%/1.7%/3.5% HoH and trade finance down 1.5% HoH. Particularly, HK property loans fell 3.9% HoH but mortgage loans grew 2.6% HoH. Deposits grew 5.8% HoH/8.8% YoY with CASA mix up 11.4ppt HoH to 58.0%. Net fee income rose strongly by 25.8% YoY in 1H (vs HSB/BEA: +22.7%/+16.6% YoY), driven by investment and insurance related business (up 79% YoY). Other non-NII surged 99% YoY in 1H with strong FX gains (+139% YoY). Revenue grew 13.3% YoY, operating cost only rose 2.3% YoY, and CIR fell 2.2ppt YoY to 20.8% in 1H.

NPLs rose 1.7% QoQ but declined 1.2% HoH with new NPL formation largely offset by write-off. NPL ratio edged up 1bp QoQ but fell 3bp HoH to 1.02%. Gross NPL formation was 39bp in 1H25 vs 7bp/45bp in 1H/2H24. China/non-China CRE accounted for 4.5%/14.7% of Group's total loans, down 0.6ppt/0.2ppt HoH, and their NPL ratios +5bp/-10bp HoH to 7.32%/1.27%, respectively, both performing much better than peers. Credit cost rose from 32bp in 1Q to 45bp in 2Q, and 1H credit cost at 39bp was 14bp higher YoY, mainly driven by HK CRE.Management sees manageable pressure in NPL ratio in 2H and expects FY25 credit cost to be similar to 1H25. NPL coverage rose 1ppt HoH to 86% (vs HSB/BEA: 30%/37%), while loan reserve coverage edged down 2bp HoH to 0.88%.

Bank of China (HK) combines the businesses of 10 of 12 HK banks that were originally under the Bank of China Group (BoCHK's controlling shareholder). With more than 300 branches in HK & China, BoCHK is HK's second-largest bank (by assets/deposits) and the largest lender. More than \(85\%\) of its EPS comes from HK. IPO: July 2002. No ADRs.

We rate BOCHK Buy on attractive valuation and dividend yield, diversified business mix, and solid earnings growth. We expect the bank to continue with the above- average volume growth, and its margin should remain strong in 2024- 25E amid the higher- for- longer US interest rate environment. BOCHK also has a relatively strong provision buffer in case of any rise in credit risks.

Our HKD37.66 price objective is based on a target \(1.1\times\) PBV multiple, derived from our Gordon Growth model, which assumes a normalized ROE of \(10.7\%\) (from \(10.4\%\) ), a cost of capital of \(10.0\%\) (from \(10.50\%\) ), a sustainable growth rate of \(2.0\%\) , and a payout ratio of around \(55 - 59\%\) , which is then applied to our 2025E BVPS estimate.
Upside risks are (1) faster-than- expected margin recovery, (2) strong volume and fee income growth in ASEAN markets, and 3) continued low NPL formation and credit costs.
Downside risk is a significant deterioration in sector asset quality.
